 1.8 Pre-Startup Review: Chobani performs a safety review of a new or modified process before the process is placed into service to ensure that the process is safe to operate.  The review confirms that an employee has completed the appropriate training.  The review also confirms that adequate safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and ensures that all construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications.  A pre-startup review checklist is completed to document the review and ensure that appropriate issues have been addressed.

 1.9 Compliance Audit: Chobani audits the process to evaluate whether the Chobani prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues present at the site.  Chobani assembles an audit team including personnel knowledgeable in the RMP rule and in the process to evaluate whether the prevention program (1) satisfies the requirements of the RMP rule and (2) whether it is sufficient to ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the audits are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate improvements to the prevention program are implemented.

 1.10 Incident Investigation: Chobani investigates all incidents that result in, or could reasonably result in a serious injury to employees, contractors, the public, and the environment in order to prevent similar incidents from recurring.  Chobani trains employees to identify and report any incident requiring investigation.  An investigation team is assembled, and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident. Risk Management Plan
Chobani, Inc.
New Berlin, NY

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Chobani is committed to operating all of its facilities in the safest possible condition to protect their employees, the public and the environment receptors located near the plant.  The New Berlin, NY yogurt manufacturer has written this document in an effort to be prepared for emergencies relating to the anhydrous ammonia, which is currently used as a refrigerant above the threshold value, and to comply with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68.  This document in conjunction with the Process Safety Management Program will be used to comply with the Title 40 regulations.
  
The Chobani facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia, CAS #7664-41-7, in its refrigeration process.  There are five separate anhydrous ammonia systems located throughout the facility.  The systems are not co-located, and therefore each system was treated as a separate process.  With the exception of system MS2, each separate process is over the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds for anhydrous ammonia.  As a precaution, release modeling was completed for all ammonia systems onsite.  Maximum, total on-site capacity for the five anhydrous ammonia systems is 61,118 pounds.

Ammonia system MS1 is a refurbished system from the existing Kraft plant.  It is designed to hold 14,597 pounds of ammonia and has components located throughout the facility.  This system refrigerates the manufacturing facility and the storage silos.  Ammonia system MS2 is located at the west end of the manufacturing facility.  It is designed to hold 4,903 pounds of ammonia and refrigerates the manufacturing tunnel.  Ammonia system MS3 is centrally located in, and refrigerates, the manufacturing facility.  It is designed to hold 20,906 pounds of ammonia.  Ammonia system DS4 is designed to hold 10,681 pounds of ammonia and is located at the west end of the distribution facility.  This system refrigerates the distribution warehouse.  Ammonia

system MS5 is located on the northwest end of the manufacturing facility in the packaging building and is designed to hold 10,031 lbs. of ammonia.  When necessary, the substance is transferred to the ammonia receivers from both canisters and delivery trucks.

Chobani uses employee/contractor training, standard operating procedures, pre-startup safety reviews, management of change procedures, hot work permitting and auditing programs as the basis for its general release prevention program.  The facility has a preventative maintenance program, a pipe and valve labeling program, and an inspection program that are related to the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system.  The management and employees of Chobani are continually looking for ways to improve the safety of the system.
 
There has been one reportable accidental ammonia release from the facility that has resulted in either an on-site or off-site consequence.

The Risk Management Program at Chobani consists of the following elements:

1. A hazard assessment to understand the potential offsite consequences of hypothetical accidental releases and a history of accidents that have occurred during the previous five years associated with the use of substances regulated by the RMP rule.
2. A prevention program to maintain and safely operate the anhydrous ammonia process containing more than the threshold quantity of substances regulated by the RMP rule.
3. An emergency response system to respond to accidental releases from the ammonia process.

Chobani meets the eligibility requirements for Program 3 under the Risk Management Plan.  Program 3 eligibility requirements necessitate that the facility put into practice a prevention program that helps to minimize the likelihood of a release from the ammonia system while also minimizing the impacts should a release occur.  The prevention program at Chobani consists of a number of elements, only 12 of which are required by the RMP rule.  The RMP rule requires the fol

lowing elements:

1. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The Chobani New Berlin facility focuses on ways to prevent an accidental release of a hazardous substance.  The following sub-sections briefly describe the elements of Chobani's prevention program for utilizing anhydrous ammonia.  Full documentation can be found in the Process Safety Management program. 

 1.1 Process Safety Information: Chobani maintains multiple documents used to provide safe operation of the process.  These documents address (1) property and hazard information on substances used in the process, (2) specific process description, and (3) design basis configuration of process equipment.

 1.2 Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS): MSDSs document the properties of hazardous substances on the premises, including anhydrous ammonia.  MSDSs are used to (1) provide health and safety information to employees, contractors and emergency responders, (2) train employees, and (3) perform Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs). MSDSs are used to provide instructions for proper handling of hazardous chemicals at the plant.  

 1.3 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): The Chobani facility performs and periodically updates PHAs for the onsite process to identify potential process hazards and generate recommendations to improve the safe operation of the process.  A team composed of personnel with engineering, environmental, process operating experience, maintenance, safety experience and a leader with process hazard analysis experience is assembled to analyze the hazards of the process.  Chobani primarily uses the what-if technique, supplemented with checklists to perform this analysis.  The PHA team prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis, including a list of recommendations to enhance the safety of the process.  Responsibility is assigned to plant personnel to resolve the recommendations.

 1.4 Operating Procedures: Chobani Managers, E

ngineers, Maintenance Operators, and Technicians work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define safe methods for performing tasks relating to the process.  Chobani personnel develop and maintain operating procedures to cover all phases of operation including; initial start-up, normal operations, normal shutdown, emergency shutdown, start-up following a turnaround, and temporary operations.  The operating procedures are used as both an instructional guide for operating the process and as a training tool for new and experienced operators.  

 1.5 Training: Workers are trained to perform their assigned tasks safely and effectively.  The Chobani training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers (1) a general overview of the process, (2) the properties and hazards associated with the process substances, and (3) a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices.  Oral review and on-the-job training are used to verify that the employee understands the process operation prior to job assignment.  The operators are consulted periodically to evaluate the effectiveness and requirement for additional training.  Recommendations from the operators are reviewed, and changes are implemented as appropriate.

 1.6 Mechanical Integrity: Chobani maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to prevent equipment failures that could endanger employees, contractors, the public and the environment.  This is accomplished by (1) an inspection and testing program to identify equipment deterioration and damage before equipment fails, (2) a management of change program to ensure that new and replacement equipment is designed to meet the standards required for service in the process, and (3) utilize personnel who are specially trained to maintain the process equipment.

 1.11 Employee Participation: The Chobani employee participation program provides a means to allow workers to participate in the development and continuous improvement of these prevention program elements.  Employees are consulted on and informed about various aspects of the prevention program through the training program.  Topics include the Process Hazard Analyses and operating procedures as well as access to any support information for the processes.

 1.12 Hot Work Permits: Chobani uses a Hot Work Permit program to control spark or flame producing activities that could result in fires or explosions at the facility.  Chobani created a Hot Work Permit form to comply with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.252(a).  Personnel performing hot work are required to have an approved permit prior to beginning their work.

 1.13 Contractors: Chobani has established  a contractor safety program that outlines expectations relating to contractor performed work at the Chobani facility, including work on a process. The program reviews the safety record of all contractors to ensure Chobani only hires contractors who can safely perform the desired job tasks.  Chobani personnel explain to contract supervisor(s); (1) the hazards of the process on which they and their employees will work, (2) Chobani safe work practices, and (3) Chobani emergency response procedures.  Chobani requires the contractor supervisor(s) to also train each of their employees prior to beginning their work on or near a process.  Chobani periodically reviews a contractor's training documents and work performance to ensure safe work practices are followed.   

2. Five Year Accident History

Chobani is required to complete a review of the processes for incidents occurring in the five-year period prior to the RMP submittal date.  The facility has experienced one (1) reportable accidental re

lease of ammonia in the past five years.  Additionally, the facility has had an ammonia release that was reported but was not required to be.  Any accidental releases from the system are investigated and recorded in accordance with the requirements found in 68.81 of the risk management regulations.  The PSM Manager will be responsible for updating the risk management plan for any reportable incidents that occur. The updates must be made within six months of the date of the incident.  

3. Emergency Response Program

The facility's Safety Manager maintains an Emergency Response Plan that provides response guidelines in the event of an emergency.  This plan provides emergency response guidelines to protect people, property and business operations, provides guidelines for the effective and efficient management of emergency response, and helps coordinate response with local emergency response agencies.  The plan covers emergencies such as: fire, chemical releases, adverse weather, flood, workplace violence, medical emergencies and bomb threats. The Safety Manager is the owner of this document and is required to provide updates as necessary.  The facility's Emergency Evacuation Plan can be viewed in Section 14 - Emergency Planning and Response of the Process Safety Management Program.  The facility's Safety Manager also maintains a Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (Hazwoper) program that is in accordance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) standard 29 CFR 1910.120.  The purpose of the Hazwoper program is to establish basic guidelines for employees to follow when responding to a release of a hazardous substance.

4. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Chobani New Berlin Facility constantly strives to improve the safety of the regulated process by (1) following recommended safe practices, (2) soliciting safety suggestions from employees, (3) conducting hazard analysis studies, and (4) researching and investigating pro
